title: Losar
hero_image_alt: Tibetan Buddhist monks performing ritual dance
short_description: Tibetan Buddhist New Year in the Himalayas - a spiritual welcome to spring.
long_description: Losar is the Tibetan New Year and welcomes both spring and the new lunar year, with each year linked to an animal and an element in the Tibetan calendar. It blends Buddhist religious observances with folk customs meant to drive away negativity and invite prosperity. Losar gives travellers a close look at Himalayan Buddhist life, with monasteries alive with chanting, incense, and ceremonial dances. High‑altitude towns such as Tawang or Leh feel transformed, with prayer flags, traditional dress, and community gatherings that make the cold season feel festive rather than harsh.
significance: Marks the beginning of the Tibetan lunar year, blending Buddhist rituals with pre-Buddhist Bön customs to ward off evil spirits.
key_rituals: Home Cleaning: Thorough cleaning and decoration with auspicious symbols before the new year.
Monastery Visits: Offerings and prayers at monasteries like Tawang or Hemis.
Masked Dances: Sacred Cham dances performed by monks to dramatize the triumph of good over evil.
Torchlit Processions: Held at night to drive away negative spirits.

practical_info.dress_tips: Heavy woolens are essential as temperatures are freezing. Dress respectfully for monasteries.
practical_info.safety_tips: Acclimatize well if visiting high-altitude areas like Leh or Tawang. Carry medications.
practical_info.accessibility_notes: Mountainous terrain can be challenging; monasteries often have stairs.

faqs.a: Some local shops may close for family celebrations, but tourist services usually remain open.
